moves.1. e4 e6: Marin plays a conservative French defense.
moves.2... d5: The standard response, and a must.
moves.3. Nc3: Solid. 3 P-K5 locks the center but without development White will be hard-pressed to hold it.
moves.4... Be7: Practically forced. The only other choice was 4... Q-Q2 to avoid losing the pinned Knight by...
moves.5. e5: ...this move, which has now been adequately prepared.
moves.5... Ne4: With the more cramped position, Marin naturally wishes to whittle down the wood. This move forces the exchange of at least one pair of minor pieces.
moves.7. Qg4: Attacking the weakened King-side at once.
moves.7... O-O: Marin tucks his King into what he *thinks* is a safe spot...
moves.8. Bd3: Threatening to win a Pawn by exchanging on K4, so...
moves.8... Nxc3: ...Marin preemptively exchanges off the Knight himself.
moves.9... c5: With Yates having a K-side spatial advantage, Marin wishes to gain space on the Q-side as a counterbalance.
moves.10. Nf3: Developing with a hidden threat. The proper defence is 10... P-KN3, cutting off the Bishop's diagonal.
moves.10... c4: Marin overlooks the threat, and is blindsided by...
moves.11. Bxh7+: ...this thunderbolt from heaven! Marin resigns at once. If 11... KxB 12 Q-R5 ch K-N1 13 N-N5, and the only way to stop mate is 13... QxN 14 QxQ leaving Marin with a hopeless disadvantage in material. [13... R-Q1 14 Q-R7 ch K-B1 15 Q-R8 mate.] And 11... K-R1 12 Q-R5 sets up a devastating discovered check that cannot be prevented.
